summary.text:
Purpose

The purpose of House Bill 1131 is to amend existing laws regarding the supervision of individuals sentenced to probation and community custody in Washington. The bill aims to clarify and expand the categories of individuals who will be supervised by the Department of Corrections and to modify the process for clemency and pardons. Key changes include adjusting the criteria for supervision to include more individuals with serious offenses and enhancing the diversity and training requirements for the Clemency and Pardons Board. The bill seeks to ensure better community safety by addressing supervision protocols and maintaining oversight of individuals with serious criminal convictions.

Key Provisions

Supervision of Individuals

  • The Department of Corrections will supervise individuals sentenced to probation, including:
    • Individuals convicted of certain sex offenses (e.g., sexual misconduct with a minor).
    • Individuals with current or prior convictions for repetitive domestic violence offenses.
  • Individuals convicted of misdemeanor offenses now must be supervised and placed on community custody.
  • The Department will supervise every individual convicted of a felony who poses a high risk of reoffending as determined by risk assessment.
  • Supervision will also be mandated for individuals with specific serious convictions irrespective of their risk classification, including sex and violent offenses.

Clemency and Pardons Board

  • The Clemency and Pardons Board is to consist of 10 members with a focus on diversity regarding race, gender, and experience with the justice system.
  • Members must undergo training related to racial equity and restorative justice.
  • The board will review petitions for commutation and pardons, ensuring recommendations are based on justice and community safety rather than overcrowding concerns.

Reporting and Oversight

  • The Clemency and Pardons Board is required to submit an annual report to the governor and legislature detailing its activities, including names of individuals granted commutation or pardon and any recidivism.

Implementation and Expiration

  • Specific provisions of the bill have set effective dates and an expiration date, with particular sections expiring on January 1, 2026, to ensure continuous review and potential adjustment.

summary.text:
Purpose

The edits made to the proposed legislature bill enhance its clarity and inclusiveness by changing terminology and adjusting sections to better reflect current laws and social perspectives. Most notably, the term offender has been changed to individual throughout the bill, which is a move towards more respectful and humanizing language. This change not only modernizes the language but also underscores a shift towards rehabilitation rather than solely punishment.

Key Changes

Terminology Changes

  • The word "offender" has been replaced with "individual" in multiple instances to promote respect and acknowledgment of the personhood of those involved in the legal system.
  • This change enhances the bill's language, making it more compassionate and aligning it with contemporary understandings of rehabilitation.

Supervision Requirements

  • The bill clarifies that the department shall supervise individuals:
  • Convicted of specific offenses, including sexual misconduct with minors, custodial sexual misconduct, and violation of registration laws.
  • Identified as high risk for reoffending based on risk assessments.

Clemency and Pardons Board Composition

  • The number of board members has increased from five to ten.
  • There are new requirements for diversity in board appointments, including ensuring inclusion of individuals from various backgrounds, emphasizing the importance of lived experiences in discussions around clemency.

Reporting Requirements

  • The clemency and pardons board is now required to report annually to the governor and legislature, including information on individuals granted commutation or pardon, their conviction details, and any recidivism observed.

Miscellaneous Adjustments

  • Added provisions about conditional commutation and the supervision of individuals meeting specific criteria to enhance clarity regarding community custody and parole.
  • Increased transparency requirements in the process of granting clemency to ensure community and victim involvement.

These changes collectively aim to modernize the approach to clemency and pardons while emphasizing rehabilitation and respect for individual dignity.

Purpose

The edits to this bill aim to clarify the language related to the supervision of individuals on probation and the process for granting clemency and pardons. The key changes simplify terminology, ensuring consistent use of "individuals" instead of "offenders," which reflects a more rehabilitative focus. Additionally, the revisions enhance transparency and accountability in the clemency process by requiring reports on commutation and pardon decisions.

Key Changes

Terminology Updates

  • The term "offenders" has been replaced with "individuals" throughout the document to promote a more rehabilitative perspective.
  • Other standard legal phrases have been updated for clarity.

Clemency and Pardons Board

  • The size of the Clemency and Pardons Board is increased from five to ten members, improving diversity and representation.
  • The board composition now mandates representation from various communities, including those with lived experience in criminal justice and community reentry.

Reporting Requirements

  • A new section now mandates the Clemency and Pardons Board to submit an annual report to the governor and legislature detailing its activities, including the names of individuals granted commutation or pardon.

New Provisions

  • A new section states that if funding for the purposes of this act is not provided by June 30, 2025, the act will become null and void. This ensures that the provisions can be implemented effectively if adequate resources are allocated.

Additional Legal Adjustments

  • The requirement of providing 90 days' notice before a hearing on clemency petitions was specified, enhancing the due process for individuals seeking pardons.
  • Clarifications were made regarding how petitions for restoration of civil rights could be processed.

These changes collectively aim to improve the administration of justice and support rehabilitation while increasing oversight for the clemency process.
